subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example
msgSnippet: ... Agreed.  Context matters. ... Good point. Along the same lines, I have had occasion to use the same single test method technique with an externalize data
messageBody:
On Nov 22, 2003, at 7:41 AM, Michael Silverstein wrote:
>
> I think it depends on the context. If I am running tests on the desktop
> I usually want to stop on the first failure, fix it and move on to the
> next one.

Agreed. Context matters.

> If we are running a large set of automated tests for a build of an
> entire system that has code that spans multiple developers, it may be
> preferable to complete the entire test with a report of multiple errors
> that the developers can scurry off with and recreate on their own, one
> error at a time. On the other hand it some times works out better to
> run
> the build tests and stop on the first error, with developers taking
> turns in the 'hot seat' to fix their problem and start the build tests
> again.

Good point.

Along the same lines, I have had occasion to use the same single test
method technique with an externalize data file, but allowing for
multiple failures to be accumulated. While looping through the "rows"
of data, the test method catches AssertionFailedError and adds it to a
collection of failures. When the test suite completes, it dumps out
any failures that were collected along the way.

Mike
